<!-- This form is for bug reports and feature requests ONLY!

If you're looking for help check [Stack Overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/kubernetes) and the [troubleshooting guide](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/debug-application-cluster/troubleshooting/).

If the matter is security related, please disclose it privately via https://kubernetes.io/security/.
-->

**Is this a BUG REPORT or FEATURE REQUEST?**:

> /kind bug

/sig windows


**What happened**:

When creating a Kubernetes pod [0], you can specify the ``terminationMessagePath`` field, which is a file in which a container can write in, and its content will be included in the Pod's status [1], in the ``status.containerStatuses.state.terminated.message`` field. However, this does not work as intended with Windows Containers, causing a few Conformance tests to fail, like:

    [k8s.io] Container Runtime blackbox test when starting a container that exits  should report termination message as empty when pod succeeds and TerminationMessagePolicy FallbackToLogOnError is set [NodeConformance]

When comparing the ``docker inspect`` results from a Kubernetes pod with a Linux Container [2] with the ones from a Kubernetes pod with a Windows Container [3], it can be seen that the Linux container has a few extra items in the ``HostConfig.Binds`` list:

            "HostConfig": {
            "Binds": [
                "/var/lib/kubelet/pods/b4a24db4-b816-11e8-a756-000d3a4d73b6/volumes/kubernetes.io~secret/default-t                                                                                                                           oken-fnq6g:/var/run/secrets/kubernetes.io/serviceaccount:ro",
                "/var/lib/kubelet/pods/b4a24db4-b816-11e8-a756-000d3a4d73b6/etc-hosts:/etc/hosts",
                "/var/lib/kubelet/pods/b4a24db4-b816-11e8-a756-000d3a4d73b6/containers/termination-message-contain                                                                                                                           er/f1f48263:/dev/termination-log"
            ],

Which means that the Windows Kubelet is not creating those mounts. However, on Windows Docker, you cannot mount individual files at the moment (although mounting a folder to ``/dev`` instead could solve this issue).

[0] https://paste.ubuntu.com/p/pBp3SKHm9J/
[1] https://paste.ubuntu.com/p/Fh5Fb6qvp4/
[2] https://paste.ubuntu.com/p/v9sRkQqWfw/
[3] https://paste.ubuntu.com/p/8zPnRwWzHd/

**What you expected to happen**:

The given pod's ``terminationMessagePath`` file should exist in the containers, and the containers should be able to write messages in it, messages which will be included in the container's ``terminated`` status.

**How to reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)**:

1. Deploy the Kubernetes pod [0]: ``kubectl create -f pod.yaml``
2. Check that the container finised and that it has no termination status: ``kubectl get -o yaml po/termination-message-pod``
3. Additionally, log into the Windows node and execute ``docker inspect`` on the Kubernetes pod's container, and check that the ``HostConfig.Binds`` does not contain the ``/dev/termination-file`` mount.

**Anything else we need to know?**:

**Environment**:
- Kubernetes version (use `kubectl version`): v1.12.0-beta.1
- Cloud provider or hardware configuration: N/A
- OS (e.g. from /etc/os-release): Windows Server 1803
- Kernel (e.g. `uname -a`): N/A
- Install tools: N/A
- Others:

title: Windows Kubelet does not mount the /dev/termination-file file into containers
